content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Linda Peacock: Well, I was born in Charleston, South Carolina, and I grew up in a small but loving family. My parents were both very involved in my life, and they placed a strong emphasis on education. My father had a graduate degree in engineering, and my mother has a bachelor's in education. She worked as a teacher for many years, which I think influenced my own path. I was raised in a Protestant household, and while I still identify as Protestant today, I've always been more interested in the moral teachings than the rituals. I moved around a bit as a kid, but I always felt a connection to the South. I went to college in the same state, where I earned my bachelor's degree in business administration. After college, I got married and started working full time in marketing. Life has been pretty steady for me, though I've always tried to stay open to new experiences and opportunities.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Linda Peacock: There was a moment during my junior year of college that really shaped my path. I had the opportunity to study abroad for a semester, which was something I had always dreamed of. My parents were supportive, but they also worried about me being so far from home. I ended up choosing to stay in the U.S. and focus on my studies, which was the safe, practical choice. Looking back, I sometimes wonder what my life would have been like if I had taken that leap. But in the end, I think staying grounded helped me build a strong foundation for my career and family life. It taught me the value of stability and responsibility, even if it meant missing out on some experiences. I've never regretted it, but I do sometimes think about what could have been.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Linda Peacock: I think, in that moment, I made a conscious choice. I weighed the pros and cons carefully, talked it over with my parents, and realized that my priorities at the time were stability and preparing for the future. I didn't want to take a risk that might have derailed my studies or my family's expectations. That said, I also know that part of growing up is learning to balance caution with curiosity. I think I made the right decision for where I was in life, but I also believe that if I had taken that chance, I would have gained a different kind of strength—one that comes from stepping outside your comfort zone. It's a lesson I've carried with me ever since.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Linda Peacock: I think my high school guidance counselor might have been able to offer some perspective, though I don't know if she would have encouraged me to take the risk. She was always focused on helping students find stable, secure paths, which aligned with what my parents wanted for me. In hindsight, I wish I had talked to someone who could have helped me see the value in both options—staying grounded and stepping out of my comfort zone. But I also know that at 20, I didn't have the same life experience or confidence to make that kind of decision without feeling like I was betraying my family's expectations. So while I can't say for sure if someone else could have made a difference, I do think having more mentors or role models who had taken similar risks might have given me the courage to try something different.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Linda Peacock: Yes, I'm married to my husband, Mark, and we have two children—Emily, who's 8, and James, who's 5. Mark works in IT, and while our careers are different, we both value hard work and family. We live in the same house I grew up in, which feels like a blessing. It's a bit of a small town feel here in Charleston, and I love that our kids can ride their bikes around the neighborhood and know all their neighbors. We're pretty involved in our church community, though I still keep my focus on the moral teachings rather than the rituals. Being a mother has been the most rewarding part of my life, and I think it's given me a new perspective on the choices I made back in college. I didn't realize how much I would value stability until I had my own family to care for. That said, I also try to encourage my kids to be curious and open to new experiences, even if it means taking some risks. I want them to have the best of both worlds—security and the courage to explore.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 1 to 5, I realize how much my life has been shaped by the choices I've made and the values I've held close. From my childhood in Charleston to my education and career, I've always prioritized stability and family, which has brought me a great deal of fulfillment. The moment in college when I chose not to study abroad was a defining point in my life, and while I sometimes wonder about the paths not taken, I know that the foundation I built has allowed me to be a strong and present mother to my two children. I also recognize the importance of balance—between caution and curiosity, between tradition and exploration. I hope that by sharing my story, I can inspire others to reflect on their own choices and find the courage to embrace both security and growth in their lives.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Linda Peacock: My immediate family includes my parents, Robert and Margaret, who still live in Charleston. My father is retired now, but he always had a passion for engineering and still tinkers with projects in his garage. My mother is more of a quiet presence these days, but she's always been my biggest supporter. We stay in touch regularly, and while we don't see each other as often as I'd like, I know they're proud of the life I've built. My brother, Daniel, lives in Atlanta and works in finance. We're close, though our lives have taken different paths. He's always been more of an adventurer than I was, and I think that's why we get along so well—he reminds me of the person I might have been if I had taken that study abroad trip. We have a good relationship, and I admire his willingness to take risks. I think family is the foundation of everything, and I'm grateful for the support and love I've always had from them.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Linda Peacock: Outside of my family, I have a few close friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them, Sarah, is a childhood friend from high school. We've stayed in touch even as our lives have taken different directions—she moved to New York for her career in fashion, while I stayed rooted in Charleston. We keep in touch through phone calls and visits, and I really value her perspective. She's always been more free-spirited than I am, which is something I admire. She encourages me to step out of my comfort zone, even if just a little, and I think that balance is important. I also have a few coworkers who have become good friends, especially those in my marketing team. We often grab coffee or lunch, and I find that these connections help me stay grounded in my career while also keeping my personal life rich and full. Friends are like family in many ways, and I'm grateful for the people who have supported me through the good times and the challenges.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Linda Peacock: I live in a quiet, family-friendly neighborhood on Magnolia Avenue, just a few blocks from where I grew up. It's one of those places where everyone knows each other, and there's a real sense of community. There are a lot of older homes here, many of them with big yards and lots of history. I love that our kids can ride their bikes around without worrying about heavy traffic, and there are always neighbors around to help out if needed. The local park is a big part of our daily life—Emily and James love playing there, and it's a great place for families to gather. We also have a small community center nearby that hosts events like holiday celebrations and book clubs, which I've started attending more often. It's a peaceful place, and I feel lucky to be raising my children here. I think it's important for them to grow up in an environment that values tradition, but also encourages them to be curious and open to the world beyond our little corner of Charleston.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Linda Peacock: I feel very safe here, which is something I really appreciate. It's not just the quiet streets or the sense of community—it's the way people look out for each other. If I'm walking my kids to school or just running errands, I never feel uneasy. There's a kind of peace that comes with knowing your neighbors and being part of something bigger than yourself. I think it's one of the reasons I chose to stay in Charleston after college. It's a place that feels like home, and I want my children to grow up with that same sense of security. Of course, no place is perfect, but I feel confident that we're in a good environment for our family.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Linda Peacock: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, the sense of community is something I truly value. I know my neighbors, and they know me. If something happens, someone is always there to help—whether it's borrowing a cup of sugar, watching the kids for a bit, or just offering a listening ear. That kind of support is rare these days, and I think it's one of the things that makes Charleston special. On the downside, sometimes the pace of life here can feel a bit slow compared to bigger cities. I know my husband and I both have careers that could take us anywhere, but we've chosen to stay rooted here. There are moments when I wonder if we're missing out on opportunities elsewhere, but at the same time, I don't think I'd want to raise my kids in a place that's too fast-paced or impersonal. It's a trade-off, but one I'm comfortable with. I think the key is finding a place where you can feel at home, and for me, that's Charleston.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10, I realize how much my family and neighborhood have shaped the person I am today. Talking about my family—my husband, my children, and my parents—reminded me of the deep roots I have in Charleston and the importance of the support system I've built over the years. It also made me think about how my choices, like staying in the same city and not taking the study abroad opportunity, have led me to this life of stability and connection. When I described my neighborhood, I felt a sense of pride in the community we're part of, and I was reminded of how much I value the safety, familiarity, and sense of belonging that this place offers. It's comforting to know that my children are growing up in an environment that feels like home, and that I can rely on the people around me. These conversations have helped me appreciate the balance I've found between tradition, family, and the small-town charm of Charleston.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Linda Peacock: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it's also full of small joys. On weekdays, I usually wake up early, around 6:30 or 7, to get the kids ready for school. Mark usually helps with breakfast, and we try to make it a family affair—sometimes pancakes, sometimes toast with peanut butter. After dropping the kids off, I head to work, which is about a 15-minute drive from home. My job in marketing is pretty routine, but I enjoy the creativity involved in planning campaigns and working with my team. I usually finish work around 5:30, then pick up the kids from school. We have dinner together most nights, and if the weather is nice, we might take a walk in the park or have a family game night. On weekends, we like to keep it relaxed—sometimes we'll go to the local farmers' market, or if there's a festival or event in town, we'll check that out. I also try to set aside some time for myself, whether it's reading, doing a puzzle, or just sitting on the porch and watching the neighborhood kids play. It's not always perfect, but I find comfort in the rhythm of it all. There's a certain peace in knowing what to expect, and I think that's something my kids appreciate too—they know they can count on us to be there for them, no matter what.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Linda Peacock: I work as a marketing coordinator for a mid-sized company that specializes in local businesses and community events. My job is pretty varied—I spend a lot of time planning campaigns, managing social media, and working with clients to promote their products or services. I typically work Monday through Friday, from around 8:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., though I often start a little earlier to get organized and finish a bit later if needed. I enjoy the creativity involved in my work, and I find it rewarding to see the impact of a successful campaign. It's not always easy balancing work and family, but I've learned to be efficient and prioritize what matters most. I also make sure to take weekends off as much as possible, because I want to be fully present for my kids and my husband. There are days when I feel like I'm juggling a lot, but overall, I feel lucky to have a job that allows me to support my family while also doing something I'm passionate about.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Linda Peacock: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to set aside time each morning for a short walk before the kids are up, just to clear my mind and start the day with some fresh air. I also enjoy reading—mostly fiction, though I do read some business books for inspiration. On the weekends, I like to get involved in community activities, like volunteering at the local food bank or helping organize events at the community center. It's important to me to give back, especially since I've benefited so much from the support of this neighborhood. I also have a small garden in the backyard, which is a bit of a project, but it's a nice way to connect with nature and teach my kids about responsibility. There's something really satisfying about growing your own food, even if it's just a few herbs and vegetables. Overall, I think these little routines help me stay balanced and remind me that life is about more than just work and family—it's about finding joy in the small things and making the most of the time we have.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Linda Peacock: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness into my mornings. I started practicing a short meditation or deep breathing exercise while I'm waiting for the kids to get ready. It's something I read about in a book on work-life balance, and I've found it helps me start the day with a calmer mindset. I also began experimenting with new recipes for breakfast, partly to keep things interesting and partly because I want to teach my kids about healthy eating. We've been trying more whole-grain options and incorporating more fruits and vegetables into our meals. It's been a small but meaningful shift, and I think it's helping me feel more present in the moments that matter most—like the time I spend with my family before the day gets too busy.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Linda Peacock: A typical weekday during the school year for my kids starts early—around 7:30 a.m. They both have to be at school by 8:15, so we try to get up with enough time to get dressed, have breakfast, and get out the door without too much stress. Emily is in third grade, and James is in kindergarten. Emily has a pretty full schedule—she has recess, lunch, and then after school, she goes to a soccer practice twice a week and a weekly art class. James is a bit younger, so his after-school routine is simpler—he usually stays with a neighbor's mom for a couple of hours while I pick him up, and then we go home. On days when he doesn't have someone to stay with, I pick him up and we have a quiet afternoon together, maybe reading a book or playing a board game. Emily's soccer practice is on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and her art class is every Friday. I think it's important for them to have some structure and activities outside of school, but I also make sure they have time to just be kids—whether it's playing in the park, helping me with the garden, or just having a family movie night on the weekends. It's a balance, but I think they're both happy with the way things are.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15, I realize how much my daily life and routines are intertwined with the values and choices I've made over the years. Talking about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how deeply rooted I am in Charleston, and how much I value the sense of community and stability that this place offers. It also made me think about how my career and personal routines have evolved to support the life I want for my family. I've come to appreciate the balance between structure and spontaneity, between work and family, and between giving back to the community and taking time for myself. These conversations have helped me see how my life, while not without its challenges, is filled with meaning and purpose. I feel grateful for the people in my life, the routines that bring me peace, and the choices that have led me to this point.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Linda Peacock: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in good shape. I try to stay active by walking every morning before the kids are up, and I've started doing some light yoga a few times a week to help with stress and flexibility. I don't have any major health issues, but I do have a mild case of asthma that I manage with an inhaler, and I make sure to avoid triggers like strong perfumes or pollen when it's high season. I also take a daily multivitamin and try to eat a balanced diet, though I'll admit I'm not perfect about it. I've been trying to cook more at home lately, which has helped me feel more in control of what my family eats. I think it's important to take care of yourself so you can take care of others, and I've learned that small, consistent habits make a big difference over time. I also make sure to get enough sleep, though it's not always easy with two kids and a busy work schedule. Overall, I feel pretty healthy and grateful for the body I have, even if I'm not always the most disciplined about it.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Linda Peacock: For me, staying healthy is both easy and hard in different ways. On the one hand, I have a strong support system—my family and friends are always encouraging me to take care of myself, and the routine of walking in the morning gives me a sense of structure that helps me stay on track. I also find that cooking at home and eating meals together as a family makes it easier to make healthier choices. But on the other hand, life can get busy, and sometimes I fall into the trap of skipping meals or not getting enough rest. With two kids and a full-time job, it's easy to feel like there's never enough time for everything. I also struggle with consistency—some days I'm on top of my health goals, and other days I'm just trying to keep up. What makes it harder is that I don't always have the time or energy to prioritize myself the way I'd like to. But I remind myself that even small efforts, like taking a walk or eating a salad instead of takeout, add up over time. I think the key is not being too hard on myself and finding ways to make healthy habits feel natural rather than like a chore.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Linda Peacock: In the past two years, I haven't had any major health issues, but there was a time when I experienced a flare-up of my asthma that was a bit concerning. It happened during the spring when the pollen count was really high, and I found myself needing to use my inhaler more frequently than usual. I had to be more careful about keeping the windows closed and using air filters in the house, which was a bit of a hassle but necessary. I also started seeing a doctor for a check-up, just to make sure everything was under control. Overall, it was a reminder that even small things can affect your health, and it made me more aware of how important it is to stay proactive about managing my condition. I've since been more consistent with my medication and have taken steps to reduce my exposure to triggers. It wasn't a big event, but it did make me think more deeply about how my health impacts my ability to take care of my family and keep up with my daily routine.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Linda Peacock: Honestly, I think my asthma flare-up was a wake-up call, but it didn't really interfere with my ability to work or care for my kids. I had to be more mindful of my environment and my medication schedule, but I was still able to keep up with my responsibilities. I did have a few days where I felt more fatigued than usual, and I had to push myself a bit harder to stay on top of things, but nothing that stopped me from doing what I needed to do. It did make me realize how much I rely on my health to be able to take care of my family, and it reinforced the importance of staying proactive about my well-being. I think if I had ignored it or not taken it seriously, it could have become a bigger issue. But as it was, it was a minor setback that reminded me to keep my health a priority.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Linda Peacock: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of gratitude and quiet growth. Life hasn't been without its challenges—there were moments when I felt stretched thin between work, family, and trying to keep up with the little things that bring me joy. But I've also found a deeper sense of contentment in the rhythm of everyday life. I've started to appreciate the small moments more—the way Emily laughs when she's trying to ride her bike without falling, or how James will sit and watch the clouds for hours, lost in his own world. I've also been reflecting more on my own journey, especially as my kids grow and start asking questions about the world beyond Charleston. It's made me think about the choices I've made and how they've shaped who I am today. I don't know if I would have chosen differently, but I do feel a sense of peace in knowing that I've built a life that's stable, loving, and full of meaning. I think that's something to be proud of.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20, I realize how much my health and daily routines are connected to the balance I strive for in life. Talking about my morning mindfulness practice and new breakfast habits reminded me of how small changes can make a big difference in how I start my day and how I feel throughout it. Discussing my health also made me think about how important it is to take care of myself—not just for my own well-being, but for the people I love. I've come to understand that staying healthy isn't about perfection, but about consistency and making choices that support the life I want to live. It's a reminder that even in the busiest of times, taking a few moments to breathe, eat well, and move my body can help me feel more grounded and present. I'm grateful for the support I have from my family and friends, and I'm learning to be kinder to myself when I don't always meet my own expectations. These conversations have helped me see that health is not just about avoiding illness—it's about nurturing the body and mind so I can show up for the people and moments that matter most.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Linda Peacock: I think I've been fortunate not to struggle with depression or anxiety in the way that some people do. That said, there have been moments—especially during the busier times with work and the kids—when I've felt overwhelmed or unsure of myself. I don't think I've ever reached the point where I needed professional help, but I have learned to recognize when I need to take a step back and prioritize my mental health. I've started incorporating more mindfulness into my routine, like the morning meditation I mentioned earlier, and that has helped me feel more centered. I also find comfort in talking to my husband or my friends when I'm feeling down, and I've come to see those conversations as an important part of staying balanced. I think it's easy to overlook mental health in the midst of everyday life, but I'm learning to be more intentional about nurturing it, just like I do with my physical health.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Linda Peacock: For my family, the past year has been one of growth and connection. My husband, Mark, has been incredibly supportive, and we've both made an effort to be more present for our kids, even in the busiest of times. Emily is starting to become more independent, which is both exciting and a little bittersweet. She's asking more questions about the world, and I find myself reflecting on my own experiences and how I want to guide her. James is still full of wonder, and I love watching him explore his curiosity about everything from insects in the yard to the stars at night. Our family has also been getting closer—whether it's through weekend hikes, movie nights, or just sitting around the dinner table sharing our day. I think the past year has reminded me of how important it is to nurture those relationships, and I'm grateful for the love and support we have in each other.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Linda Peacock: For me, religion has always been more about the values and teachings than the rituals or traditions. I was raised Protestant, and while I still identify as Protestant today, I don't attend church services regularly. What matters most to me is the sense of morality and community that comes with it. I believe in kindness, honesty, and doing what's right—not just for myself, but for others. My faith has been a quiet presence in my life, guiding me through difficult decisions and reminding me of the importance of family and love. I think of it more as a personal compass than something I need to follow strictly. I also find comfort in knowing that I'm not alone in my beliefs, and that there are people around me who share similar values. In that way, religion has been a part of my life, even if not in the way it is for others.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Linda Peacock: I do use social media, though not as much as some of my friends. I have a Facebook account where I keep in touch with family and old friends, especially those who have moved away or are less active in our local community. I find it helpful for sharing updates about our family, like when Emily learns something new in school or when we have a special event. I also follow a few local pages for community news and events, which helps me stay connected to what's happening in Charleston. I don't use Instagram or other visual platforms as much because I prefer the more personal, text-based conversations that Facebook allows. I think it's important to stay connected with people, even if it's just through a few messages or a shared photo. That said, I also try to be mindful of how much time I spend online, because I want to make sure I'm present for my kids and not distracted by my phone. It's a balance, but I think social media has its place in keeping relationships alive, even when life gets busy.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Linda Peacock: I think social media has been a helpful tool for me during tough times, though I don't rely on it as much as some people might. When I've had a particularly busy week or felt overwhelmed with work and family responsibilities, I've found comfort in reaching out to friends or family through Facebook messages. It's amazing how a simple 'I'm having a rough day' can lead to a conversation that reminds you you're not alone. I've also found that sharing small victories—like when Emily got her first A on a test or when we had a quiet, peaceful weekend—can bring a sense of connection and joy. That said, I don't use it as a primary source of support. For me, it's more about staying in touch and sharing moments rather than seeking emotional or financial help. I think the real support comes from the people I know in person, and social media just helps bridge the distance when we can't be together.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25, I realize how much my health and mental well-being are intertwined with the daily rhythms of my life. Discussing my asthma flare-up reminded me of how even small health challenges can serve as wake-up calls, pushing me to be more proactive about my care. It also made me appreciate how my body and mind are connected—when I feel physically well, it's easier to stay mentally balanced, and vice versa. Talking about my mental health brought up the importance of recognizing when I need to pause and take a step back, even if just for a few minutes. I've come to see mindfulness and self-compassion as essential tools for navigating the demands of work, family, and life in general. It's comforting to know that I don't have to be perfect in my health or mental state, but that small, consistent efforts can make a meaningful difference. These conversations have helped me feel more in tune with myself and more grateful for the support I have from my family and friends.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Linda Peacock: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have remained fairly steady, though there have been a few moments where I felt more overwhelmed than usual. With the kids growing up and the demands of work, I've had to find new ways to manage my emotions and stay centered. One thing that's helped me is continuing my morning mindfulness practice—it's become a small but powerful way to start the day with intention rather than reacting to whatever comes my way. I've also found that talking things through with my husband or a close friend has been a great emotional release. I've learned to be more honest with myself about when I need to pause and take a breath, even if it's just for a few minutes. I think the key has been recognizing that stress is a natural part of life, but it doesn't have to control me. I've also started journaling a bit more, which helps me process my thoughts and reflect on what's really important. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of my emotional well-being is just as important as taking care of my physical health.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Linda Peacock: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to our kids' activities and groceries. Emily's soccer and art classes add up, and with James starting to get into more toys and books, it's surprising how quickly the money adds up. We also had a few unexpected costs, like a new air filter for the house after my asthma flare-up and a small repair on the car. Groceries are a regular expense, and I've been trying to be more mindful of budgeting for healthy meals. We also set aside money for our monthly bills—electricity, water, internet, and the mortgage. I think the most important part of our budget is making sure we have enough for the kids' needs and some savings for the future. It's not always easy, but I've learned to track our spending more carefully, and I've started using a budgeting app to help us stay on top of things. It's a balancing act, but I feel like we're managing it well for now.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Linda Peacock: Last month, our household spent around $3,500, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. We typically spend about $3,400 to $3,600 each month, depending on the kids' activities and any unexpected expenses. The largest portion of our budget goes toward groceries, which we try to keep as healthy as possible, and our kids' extracurriculars—Emily's soccer and art classes are a big part of that. We also have regular bills like the mortgage, utilities, and internet, which are all set on autopay to make things easier. I also set aside a small amount each month for savings, even if it's just a few hundred dollars. It's not always easy to stick to the budget, especially when we have to buy last-minute supplies or when the kids want something new, but I've found that using a budgeting app helps keep us on track. It's a balancing act, but I feel like we're managing it well for now, and I'm grateful that we have a stable income that allows us to provide for our family without too much stress.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Linda Peacock: We own our home, which is something I'm really proud of. It's the same house I grew up in, and it's been in my family for generations. My parents helped us with the down payment when we got married, and it's been a great investment over the years. Owning a home has given us a sense of stability, especially with the kids growing up here. It's not without its challenges—maintaining a house, especially with two kids and a garden, can be a lot—but I think it's worth it. There's something comforting about knowing we have a place to call our own, and I hope my children will feel the same way about it when they're older. It's also a reminder of how far we've come, from being young and starting out to building a life here in Charleston.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Linda Peacock: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, just like the seasons. In the winter, our heating costs went up a bit, which was expected, but we managed by keeping the thermostat a little lower and wearing extra layers. Then, when spring came, the pollen season hit hard, and I had to invest in a new air filter and some allergy medication, which added to the monthly expenses. During the summer, we used more electricity for the air conditioning, and we also had a small repair on the car that we hadn't anticipated. On the flip side, our utility bills were a bit lower in the fall when we switched to using more natural light and turned off unnecessary appliances. We also had a few holiday expenses—like Christmas decorations and gifts for the kids—that pushed our spending a little higher than usual. But overall, I think we've been pretty consistent, and I've learned to plan a bit more ahead, especially for things like school supplies or seasonal maintenance. It's not always perfect, but I feel like we're managing it well, and I'm grateful for the stability that comes with owning our home.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30, I realize how much my family and my approach to social media are intertwined with my sense of connection and well-being. Talking about my family reminded me of how deeply I value the love and support we share, especially as my children grow and begin to explore the world on their own. It also made me think about how my own experiences—like the choice I made in college—have shaped the kind of parent I am today. Discussing social media brought up the ways I stay connected with others, even when life gets busy. I've come to see it as a tool that helps me maintain relationships, especially with friends who live far away, but I also recognize the importance of being present in the moment with my family. I've learned that while social media can be a helpful bridge, it's not a substitute for real, in-person connections. These conversations have helped me appreciate the balance I've found between staying connected with others and being fully present for the people who matter most in my life.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Linda Peacock: I do have a savings account, and I try to save consistently, even if it's just a small amount each month. I've learned that it's not about saving a lot all at once, but about making it a habit. I set aside a portion of our paycheck automatically, and I also keep a separate jar for smaller, more immediate goals—like saving up for a family trip or a new toy for the kids. I think having that sense of financial security is important, especially with two children and the ongoing costs of raising a family. It's not always easy to resist the urge to spend, but I've found that having a savings plan gives me peace of mind. I also try to be mindful of our expenses and look for ways to cut back when necessary, like buying groceries in bulk or using coupons. I know that saving is something I can't always control completely, but I'm grateful that I've made it a priority for our family's future.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Linda Peacock: In the last year, I've been saving for both big things and for unexpected moments. We've been setting aside money for a family trip to visit my brother in Atlanta—something we've been talking about for a while now. It's a way to give the kids a chance to see a different part of the country and to spend some quality time with family. At the same time, I've also been building up an emergency fund, just in case something unexpected comes up, like a car repair or a medical expense. I think it's important to have both kinds of savings—planned and unplanned—because life can be unpredictable. I've also been trying to teach my kids about saving, even in small ways, like putting aside some of their allowance for something they really want. It's not about having a lot, but about being prepared and making choices that support the life we want to build together.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Linda Peacock: I work as a marketing coordinator for a mid-sized company that specializes in local businesses and community events. My job is pretty varied—I spend a lot of time planning campaigns, managing social media, and working with clients to promote their products or services. One of the most important parts of my role is understanding the needs of the community we serve. Charleston is such a unique place with its rich history and tight-knit neighborhoods, and I enjoy helping local businesses connect with the people who live here. I also work closely with my team to develop creative strategies that not only drive engagement but also support the values of the community. There are days when it feels like I'm juggling a thousand things at once, but I find satisfaction in knowing that my work helps bring people together and supports the local economy. It's not always easy balancing work and family, but I've learned to be efficient and prioritize what matters most. I also make sure to take weekends off as much as possible, because I want to be fully present for my kids and my husband. There are days when I feel like I'm juggling a lot, but overall, I feel lucky to have a job that allows me to support my family while also doing something I'm passionate about.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Linda Peacock: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it can sometimes stretch a bit longer depending on deadlines or special projects. My schedule is pretty standard—Monday through Friday, from about 8:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., but I often start a little earlier to get organized and sometimes stay late if I need to wrap up a campaign or meet with a client. I've learned to be efficient with my time, especially since I have two kids and a busy home life. I try to leave work at a reasonable hour so I can be there for them when they get home from school. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I've come to appreciate the structure it gives me. I also make sure to take weekends off as much as possible, because I want to be fully present for my family. There are days when I feel like I'm juggling a lot, but overall, I feel lucky to have a job that allows me to support my family while also doing something I'm passionate about.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Linda Peacock: No, I haven't had more than one job. I've always focused on having a stable, full-time position that allows me to be present for my family. My job in marketing has been my main source of income, and I've found that it gives me the flexibility I need to balance work and home life. I've considered taking on side projects or part-time work in the past, especially when we had unexpected expenses or when I wanted to save more, but I've always prioritized my family and the stability that comes with a single, reliable job. I think it's important to have a clear focus, especially when you're raising children and trying to build a life that feels secure. I've been lucky that my current role has allowed me to grow professionally while still being able to show up for the people I love.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Linda Peacock: In total, our household made around $6,500 in the past month. That includes my full-time salary from marketing, plus Mark's income from his work in IT. We've always tried to keep our finances stable, and I think it's helped us feel more secure, especially with the kids growing up and the ongoing costs of raising a family. I know it's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our bills, save a little for the future, and still enjoy the little things in life—like a family dinner out or a weekend trip to the beach. I'm grateful for the work we both do, and I think it's a good reminder that even with the challenges of balancing work and family, we're doing okay.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Linda Peacock: I've been at my current job for about seven years now, and I've really come to appreciate the stability and benefits it offers. One of the things I value most is the health insurance—it covers both my family and me, which is a huge relief, especially with my asthma and the ongoing costs of managing that. We also get a generous amount of paid time off, which is something I've learned to use wisely. I take a few weeks off each year to recharge, and I make sure to use my sick days when I need them, rather than pushing through when I'm not feeling well. The company also offers some professional development opportunities, like workshops on digital marketing or leadership training, which I've taken advantage of to grow in my role. I think having a job that not only pays well but also supports your well-being is rare, and I'm grateful for that. It's one of the reasons I've stayed in this position for so long—it's a job that allows me to do meaningful work while also taking care of my family.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Linda Peacock: I would say my relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a good rapport with my manager, Sarah, who's been with the company for over a decade. She's supportive and always encourages us to bring our ideas to the table. I think she sees potential in me, and that's something I really appreciate. As for my coworkers, we've built a strong team dynamic over the years. We often collaborate on projects, and while we have our busy moments, there's always a sense of camaraderie. We joke around, we help each other out when things get tight, and I think that makes the workplace feel more like a community than just a job. I've been lucky to work with people who are not only skilled but also kind and understanding. It's one of the reasons I've stayed in this role for so long—it's a place where I feel valued and supported, both professionally and personally.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Linda Peacock: My work schedule is pretty predictable, which I actually appreciate, especially with the way my life is structured at home. I work Monday through Friday, usually from 8:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., though I sometimes start a bit earlier or stay a little later depending on the workload. The company is pretty flexible when it comes to hours, as long as we meet our deadlines and keep communication open. I've taken advantage of that flexibility a few times, like when I needed to leave early for a school event or stay late to finish a project. That said, I do value the routine it gives me—it helps me balance everything else in my life, from picking up the kids to keeping up with the garden. I think predictability is something I've come to rely on, especially as a working parent. It gives me a sense of control, even on the busiest days.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Linda Peacock: Overall, I feel pretty content with our financial situation. It's not extravagant, but it's stable enough to cover our needs and give us some room to enjoy life. I know we're not rolling in wealth, but I also know that we've made choices that prioritize what's important—like having a home, providing for our kids, and being able to take care of each other. There are moments when I worry about the future, especially with the cost of raising children and the possibility of unexpected expenses, but I also feel grateful that we've built a life that's secure. I think the key for us has been balance—making sure we're not overspending, but also not being too rigid with our budget that we miss out on the little joys. I'm proud of how we've managed to stay afloat, and I hope that as our kids grow, they'll understand the value of financial responsibility and the importance of making choices that support the life we want to build together.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Linda Peacock: Yes, both my parents worked while I was growing up. My father was an engineer, and he worked full time for a company that specialized in infrastructure projects. My mother was a teacher, and she worked at the same school for most of my childhood. They both had stable careers, which gave me a sense of security and taught me the value of hard work. I remember my mother always coming home tired but happy, and my father would often come home with stories about his projects. They both made sacrifices to provide for our family, and I think that's why I value stability so much today. I also remember how important it was for them to be present in my life, even with their busy schedules. They always made time for family dinners, school events, and weekend trips. It taught me that work and family can coexist, as long as you prioritize what matters most.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Linda Peacock: My father worked as an engineer for a company that specialized in infrastructure projects, like designing and overseeing the construction of bridges and roads. His most important activities involved working closely with teams of architects, contractors, and government officials to ensure that projects were completed on time and met safety standards. He often spent long hours at the office or on site, but he always made it a point to come home for dinner and to be involved in our family life. My mother was a teacher at the local elementary school, and her most important duties included planning lessons, grading papers, and working with students to help them reach their full potential. She also spent a lot of time communicating with parents and organizing school events. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always found ways to balance work and family, and I think that's something I carry with me today. Their dedication to their careers and their family taught me the importance of responsibility, hard work, and making time for the people you love.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Linda Peacock: My father worked for a civil engineering firm that was involved in a lot of public infrastructure projects, especially in the Southeast. They designed and managed the construction of roads, bridges, and water systems. It was a company that worked closely with local and state governments, and my father often had to travel to different parts of the country for projects. He was very detail-oriented and had a strong sense of responsibility, which I think is why he was so respected in his field. My mother worked for the Charleston Public Schools system, and she taught third grade for most of her career. She loved her job, and I think she found a lot of fulfillment in helping children learn and grow. Both of them were in stable, well-established professions, which gave me a sense of security growing up. I think their work ethic and dedication to their jobs are part of why I value stability and responsibility in my own life today.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Linda Peacock: If I imagine myself a few years from now, I hope I'm still here in Charleston, raising my kids in the same neighborhood where I grew up. I hope they're growing into thoughtful, curious, and kind young adults—people who value both stability and the courage to explore the world. I hope I'm still working in marketing, but maybe with a little more influence or responsibility, something that allows me to make a meaningful impact in our community. I also hope that Mark and I are still enjoying our marriage, still finding ways to laugh and connect, even as life gets busier. I hope we're still having family dinners, still going to the park, and still finding joy in the little things. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I hope it's filled with love, growth, and the same sense of peace and purpose that I feel right now.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Linda Peacock: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—both with my family and with the community I live in. I value the love and support of my husband, Mark, and the way we've built a life together that prioritizes our children's well-being and our shared happiness. I value the stability of our home in Charleston, the familiar streets, the neighbors who feel like family, and the traditions that ground us. I also value the lessons I've learned over the years—about balance, about making choices that reflect who I am, and about finding strength in both staying rooted and being open to growth. Most of all, I value the moments that matter: the laughter of my children, the quiet evenings with my husband, and the simple joys of a life that, while not perfect, feels full and meaningful.
